content.text: DNS (Domain Name System) is like the phone book of the internet, translating human-readable domain names (like example.com) into IP addresses that computers use to communicate. DNS security is crucial because DNS misconfigurations can lead to serious security breaches.

If DNS configuration is incorrect or compromised, hackers can redirect your legitimate website traffic to malicious sites (DNS hijacking), steal user credentials, perform phishing attacks, or intercept sensitive data. DNS is often the first point of attack in sophisticated cyber attacks.

items: DNS record resolution (A records, AAAA records)
SPF, DKIM, DMARC records for email security

content.title: DNS Hijacking
content.text: Attackers redirect legitimate DNS queries to malicious servers, sending users to fake websites that steal credentials or install malware. This can happen at the router level, ISP level, or through malware.

content.title: DNS Spoofing (Cache Poisoning)
content.text: Attackers inject false DNS records into a DNS resolver's cache, causing it to return incorrect IP addresses for legitimate domains. Users are then redirected to malicious sites.

content.title: DNS Tunneling
content.text: Attackers use DNS queries to exfiltrate data or establish command and control channels, bypassing network security controls that might block other protocols.

content.title: DDoS Attacks on DNS
content.text: Attackers overwhelm DNS servers with traffic, making websites unreachable even though the servers themselves are functioning correctly.

items: Use DNSSEC (DNS Security Extensions) to authenticate DNS responses
Use reputable DNS providers with DDoS protection
Regularly audit DNS records for unauthorized changes
Implement SPF, DKIM, and DMARC for email security
Use DNS filtering to block malicious domains
Enable DNS over HTTPS (DoH) or DNS over TLS (DoT)
Monitor for DNS anomalies and suspicious queries

content.title: DNSSEC
content.text: DNSSEC adds cryptographic signatures to DNS records, allowing resolvers to verify that DNS responses are authentic and haven't been tampered with.

content.title: DNS over HTTPS (DoH) / DNS over TLS (DoT)
content.text: Encrypts DNS queries to prevent eavesdropping and manipulation. DoH uses HTTPS protocol, while DoT uses TLS protocol for DNS queries.
